description:
The Simon Optix game takes the Simon game to exciting heights.

Put on the headset and get ready to watch, remember, repeat!

The innovative Simon Optix game is a wearable electronic game of lights and sounds in which players must repeat random sequences of lights by moving their hands in the correct order. 
The suspense builds as the sequence gets longer! 
Play solo or with friends in Sync Mode (requires additional headsets, which are sold separately and are subject to availability). 
No matter which mode they play, kids can challenge themselves to beat their high score!

—description from the publisher

Darbak Khadar is a race to reach the final green square on the canvas. It can be played as individuals or as competing teams of two.

You toss the colored ball, and the color you get determnes the square you need to move to. If you get a green color you move to the next green box on the canvas and play again. If you land on an elevator squares you toss the ball again to figure out whether you go down, up or forward depending on the color you get.

In the magical realm of Zaberias four tribes are fighting to conquer the whole realm: The Guardians, Orcs, Humans, and Undead.

It is a strategy-level war game. A player must conquer new fortresses and upgrade existing ones so to increase income, and gain access to stronger and bigger units. Each unit has different innate skills (power, range, & speed), and some special abilities which add many strategic maneuvers, fun, and replay-ability.

The game is straight forward and easy to learn; it does not limit the player but rather gives freedom of action. In each turn, a player can receive money, build units, upgrade fortresses, move and attack as much as his resources and units allow him. There is no specific action sequence. a player can do what suits him best.

Some movie clichés are necessary, others just the result of lazy screenwriting. But they're always fun to predict and spot! That's why we turned 75 of them into playing cards!

Two styles of play ("Cliché Bingo" and "Name the Movies") are the meat of the game - but you can surely come up with different scenarios.

The Action Edition is available as a standalone edition and as part of the complete edition (action, horror, comedy, sci-fi and fantasy clichés).

—description from the designer

Some movie clichés are necessary, others just the result of lazy screenwriting. But they're always fun to predict and spot! That's why we turned 180 of them into playing cards!

Two styles of play ("Cliché Bingo" and "Name the Movies") are the meat of the game - but you can surely come up with different scenarios.

As Action and Horror are the most cliché-filled genres, most cards fall into these categories. Therefore Action and Horror are also available as Standalone editions, whereas Comedy and SciFi & Fantasy are only available in this Complete Edition.

—description from the designer

A card game where in the players attempt to build the most successful arcade by building new machines and drawing in people from the community. they can also sabotage the other players machines by placing them out of order.

On the players turn they can either play a machine/upgrade into their arcade. Or they can place a meeple from the community onto an existing machine/upgrade.

Out of order/repaired cards can be played at anytime to effect machines in play.

When the first player has 6 machines in their arcade the game is over and a meeple count determines the winner of the game.

—description from the designer

You're going places! But what you take on your journey isn't up to you to decide, and the the people who are "packing your bag" don't know exactly where you're going. Still, they're doing their best, and you'll pick the person who packs the best combination of items for you. Between you, you'll figure out What goes to Where.

What To Where!? is a hilarious party game of questions, answers, and storytelling.

The game is played in rounds - play one round or play 20, whatever you want. Each round, one player (called the Traveler) secretly takes a Destination card which indicates where they're going. The other players have a predetermined number of Question Actions denoted by chips, and in the center of the table a pile of Item Tiles, all unique. All at the same time, the players who are not the Traveler sift through the Items, trying to pick the very best set of four for the Traveler to take with them. Meanwhile, the players may cash in chips to ask limited Questions that will narrow down where the Traveler is going.

Once all of the Question Actions have been taken (all the chips spent), the Traveler reveals their Destination and all players reveal the Items they selected. Then everyone gets a chance to tell a story to justify why they picked what they did. The Traveler chooses who "packed" the set of items and declares that player the winner for the round.

—description from the publisher

Gas building up around the cows eventually might explode! Spread them out before we're all killed!

The community is concerned about all the gas building up around the cows. Eventually it might explode! Move your cows to an open pasture where they can air out their farts before they kill us all!

You will each start with a set of cows and terrain cards. Each turn, you will either place a terrain card or maneuver a cow. The cows will each take up a different amount of space. Terrain also varies in usable space. Terrain that allows more maneuverability is worth more victory points at the end of the game. Cows are movable as long as they aren’t farting. Once they are farting, they are won’t be movable for the remainder of the game. Cows can also take up more of the usable terrain space by farting, so time those gaseous releases appropriately. The game ends after any player places their last terrain card on the table, with one final turn for each other player. After that, the player having the most cows on any given terrain card will claim the victory points for the space.

—description from designer
A fast paced word game. Everyone plays at the same time, trying to sort cards into a predefined order based on the letters included of the depicted object.

Killjoy: Pocket Play is the anti-party game. This 52-card game is an action-packed good time for 2-4 players.

Jerry is the guy from work who throws the worst parties. When you tell him you can't go, he starts asking questions.

Your goal is to be the first player to escape Jerry's party by answering all 3 of his questions with appropriate excuses.

But, move quickly! Your friends don't plan on going either, and they might notice you experiencing things like a Panic Attack or Sweaty Palms.

The first player to escape 3 parties will be crowned the ultimate killjoy.

Great for non-gamers, new gamers, light gamers, and anyone wanting a quick fun round!

—description from the designer

The Laughing Man, a mysterious criminal, is terrorizing the city of Niihama. Will Section 9 agents be able to contain the threat in this first board game adaptation of legendary anime Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex?

In a near future where the frontier between humankind and machines has almost disappeared, a mysterious criminal known as the Laughing Man tries to create chaos and terror among the inhabitants of the Japanese city of Niihama. Only Section 9, an elite task force of military officers and police detectives who deal with cybercrimes and terrorist threats can prevent the fall of the city. This is war, and only one side will triumph!

For the first time ever, Ghost in The Shell becomes a boardgame
Asymmetric gameplay: one player is the the Laughing Man, the others must work together as Section 9 to save the city from his attacks.
A vividly illustrated game featuring a modular game board, finely crafted miniatures and a robust deckbuilding system.

Hard decisions for both sides!

—description from the publisher

Wishland is a worker placement eurogame based on the management of a theme park. Through a series of rounds players will purchase different cards from the board to create their own and unique theme park.

The game last 7 rounds. At the end of the game, the player with the most victory points is declared the winner.

There are 5 different types of cards in the game:

Restaurants: Increases the base income of players.

Actors: Add additional workers, happiness and visitors. They also earn victory points at the end of the game with a set collection mechanic.

Rides: The heart of a theme park. You need a minimum amount of rides in order to enlarge your theme park. They also provide victory points.

Hotels: Some allow you to ignore some game rules, while other give you end game objectives or direct rewards related to the other types of cards.

Mascots: Can make a big difference in the end game. All cards of the game have an icon on them. Each of the 12 different mascouts gives you points at the end of the game for each card sharing icons with them.

-description from designer

A further book that expands Bob Cordery's Portable Wargame system, featuring small and quick games on square or hex-grid terrain.  This contains rules for ancient warfare and aerial warfare in the first half of the twentieth century.  It also contains additional and optional rules for the rulesets featured in the previous "The Portable Wargame" book.  The book concludes with some example mini-campaigns and scenarios.

Sanctorvm is a cooperative SF horror game for 1 and up to 6 players with a massive campaign, blending aspects of roleplaying and Choose Your Own Adventure books. Develop your character, find the best weapons, and work together to survive the colony menaces and advance in the Overlord’s plot. Also has a Mission Mode (1-5) without Overlod. There are two ways to play Sanctorvm:

Adventure Mode (1 to 6 players): This mode has a massive RPG campaign (15 sessions, minimum of 4 hours per session) with narrative and action missions. One player will play as the Overlord, while the others play as La Familia, our heroes. Develop your character, find the best weapons, and work together to survive the colony menaces as you advance in the Overlord’s plot.
 Mission Mode (1 to 6 players): This mode only has action missions (1 hour per mission) to be played in a single session without need for an Overlord.

Type: Thematic, Adventure, Science Fiction, Horror, and Co-op
Number of players: 1-6
The time required:  3-4 Hours per session (Adventure Mode) & 1 Hour per mission (Mission Mode)
Recommended ages: 18+

The players will embody La Familia, six superhumans on Colony 401, experiments of an old fanatic named Dr Rabidus. You have to overcome the challenges and trials of the abyss, survive hellish creatures born of a mysterious virus, and escape the yoke of four powerful factions. Cooperate with your friends and other allies, evolve your Homo Superbe, and overcome the narrative challenges that could decide your path and end of the story.

Welcome to Sanctorvm, or not…

HOW TO PLAY
Sanctorvm is a board game in which one player gets to be the master and Overlord of the adventure while up to five players assume five characters (Homo Superbe/La Familia). 
During every game, the players must fight dangerous creatures and make choices that may change the story. They will also acquire gear, upgrade abilities, and try to survive through the story that the Overlord develops.
Sanctorvm uses a unique dice-based system. Every character gets a number of action dice based on the required ability and their homo superbe powers which they use to get through battles and struggles in the narrative.
With double-sided tokens, different card combinations, and an immersive lore-rich adventure with countless options, Sanctorvm teleports players to a frenetic, violent kingdom where La Familia must fight together to survive.
The goal of the game is basic survival, along with developing your character and creating strategies alongside your partners to succeed in different missions. In the Adventure Mode, there are different scenes where the players will have to choose sides, changing the game and making every session unique.

—description from the publisher

Color matching hexagonal card game. Deck consists of sixty cards.

The hexagonal cards are divided into six colors per card out of a possible nine colors.

GAME PLAY


     2 to 4 players are dealt 7 cards each,
     5 to 7 players are dealt 5 cards each.


Players take turns dealing, person to the left of the dealer goes first. Game starts by player one laying a card face up on the table and drawing a card from the deck. Player two tries to match color to color, then, the next player and so on, the winner is the first one to play all their cards, white wedge is a wild color, black wedge blocks any match. If a player matches.


     ONE color you draw a card and your turn ends 
     TWO colors, you don’t draw a card and your turn ends 
     THREE colors, you don’t draw a card and you get to take another turn 
     FOUR colors, you give a player of choice one of your care   and you get to take another turn 
     FIVE colors and you automatically win the game 
     (SIX colors and you win this and the next six games, there is no need to play them.)

Philadelphia 1777 is a board wargame about the American Revolutionary War campaign led by British General Howe against the American colonist led by General Washington. It is a point to point movement war game using blocks with labels for the military units. The game uses the system from our previous games, New York 1776, Trenton 1776, and Saratoga 1777.

Each turn both the American and British player will receive activation points with which to activate either groups of blocks moved by a leader, or individual blocks. When blocks of both sides end a move in a location together then a battle occurs.

The game has some excellent historical “chrome” mixed in.

There are lots of great strategic decisions for both sides in the game. Best of all it plays in 2 hours so you have time to play two games in an evening.

—description from the designer

The object of the game is to play four of your words from your word cards out onto the board, and score a higher number of points than any other player when the game ends. Each player has 4 word cards, each with 4 words on it and each word 5 letters long. However, each word is an English word spelled out phonetically. On a player's turn they play one of their words out to the board using the letter tiles, similar to Scrabble except players have access to all letters at all times. Once a word is played all other players can make 3 guesses among them what they think the words actually is. If they fail to say the word correctly, the current player earns an additional 10 points. Regardless, players earn points when placing words based on the squares on the board they lay their words. After four rounds, the player with the most points is the winner.

This is game #5 of a series from Things Unlimited.

Terra Incognita: Real Theory of Everything is a game in which players represent one of two factions: scientists or conspiracy theorists. They must decide once and forever: is Earth flat or spherical?

During the game, players build a deck by selecting the appropriate cards from one of the factions. In this way, players can accumulate points of Hidden Truths or Science which can then be used to change the world. Literally!

Points of Hidden Truths and Science allow the player to buy tiles that are used to build a map of the whole world. It’s up to them if Earth will be flat or not! It ensures appropriate actions which can strengthen your decks.

At the very end – there can only be one winner! The person who wins is going to be the most powerful and - very likely - will change the face of the world forever!

Highlights:

     A great combination of classical deck-building mixed with tile-placement game. The world hasn’t seen something like that yet! Call your mom, call your boss, and gather a team to play! The unique, fresh mechanics and immersive experience of a dynamic, interesting play for gamers on every age is seriously mind blowing! You simply cannot miss that. 
     An incredible sense of humor - get your sores ointment ready, because as a result of compulsive laughter caused by the game you will have to lubricate your cheeks and stomach!
     Be whoever you want in the game - we won’t judge! 


Do you want to prove that Earth is flat, vaccines cause autism, governments poison us using chemtrails, UFO kidnaps people, everything is caused by Illuminati, Big Foot and Loch Ness Monster exist? Now you can! 
Do you want to save the world from these above and you believe in science? In this game you can even land on Mars and design a new cancer vaccine to benefit mankind, so let’s go!

—description from the publisher

Verkopft is a fast pacing card game from the publishing company Simon & Jan, released in June 2019.

It gained regional fame as the publishers decided to give away 700 units of this game for free to non-profit organizations.

Verkopft is a game about speed and focus. Every card contains 4 different information:

     a background color
     a fruit
     a text
     a textcolor


Players must handle all these (partially conflicting) information under time pressure and name the information that is looked for in this round.

The game utilizes a psychologicial effect called the stroop effect. This effect describes a converting conflict within a human's brain when several conflicting information appear.

—description from the publisher

In Let's Sort It Out take turns picking and sorting recyclables, trash and compost to gain points in this set-collection game. Watch as they come down the conveyor belt. Collect the best cards to fill your bins. But watch out for hazardous materials! They will contaminate your hand and hinder you in the game.

—description from the designer

An exciting game played on the high seas to save the world's threatened whale population.

Drop anchor in Pago Pago, Darwin, Amchitka. Fiji, and other interesting ports of call.

Navigate the far reaches of the Pacific in search of whaling fleets.

Contains two versions: 1 for 8 years and Up, II for 12 years and up.

Contains playing board of the Pacific Ocean, 2 dice, 8 plastic ships, 32 whale cards, 29 Davy Jones Locker cards, 16 confrontation cards, and a rule sheet,

Eiswürfeln (or 'Ice Cream Dice') is a fast-paced dice game for ice cream lovers of all ages. With a dash of luck and a big scoop of risk-taking fun, you’ll spend each round rolling dice to get the right types of ice cream so you can assemble a tasty sundae and earn points. You can grab extra points if you create a sundae which matches the target exactly. But be careful: if you get too
greedy and don’t roll enough money to pay for the ice cream at the end, you’ll finish the round empty-handed. You should also avoid rolling too many suns, or your ice cream will melt along
with your points. Whoever reaches 25 points or more after several rounds wins the game.

—description from the publisher

The entity known as Chaos began the formation of a new planet an attracted the attention of the whole cosmos. From every corner of the universe, the gods of creation came together for a big competition!

In Deusastrados, players assume the role of these gods, striving to fulfill the orders of Chaos and generate the best and most adapted creatures to populate the new planet.

Rounds in Deusastrados are divided into four phases:

CREATION
Players, in real-time and simultaneously, draw creature parts cards from the center of the table and use them to build their creatures, or to sabotage their opponents' creatures.

POWERS
Players check their god's available power cards and choose one to lay face-down on the table. All of them are revealed simultaneously and they are activated in order of priority.

CHAOS
All creatures with parts unwanted by Chaos discard those parts.

SCORING
The remaining creatures and parts score, following the rules.

Deusastrados has a basic mode and an asymmetrical one, in which each god has his own ability and distinct powers.

The king is getting anxious and hungry, it is past noon and the table is set.
In the castle pantry, the cooks hurry up gathering ingredients and preparing the finest delicacies for the banquet, while helpers are piling up the place, stacking trays and plates. Tension hangs in the air until a scream tears the silence "Serve the King!"

In Sirvam o Rei, players take on the role of these cooks.
Each player starts with four cards face down in front of them, representing the available recipes. During his turn, a player draws a new card from the deck and decides whether to discard it (activating its ability if he wishes) or trade it without revealing it for any of his other recipes. At any time, a player may skip his turn by exclaiming "Serve the King" and activate the last round.

There are 4 kings and 1 queen with different tastes that modify the final goal and the importance of certain recipes. Whether it is the Ogre King who is disgusted by sweets and fresh foods or the Elven Sea Queen who has very strong opinions on seafood recipes, it's up to the players to adapt their cooking to the demands and present the best dishes of the banquet.

—description from the publisher

The Head Oracle is gravely ill. A terrible storm has torn through the land, filling the people with fear. They turn to you; oracles of the temple, sacred predictors of the future. You must guide them.

You will take on the roll of oracles and vie for the favor of the ailing head of your temple. Constellation cards dictate star patterns you must create on the shared board, but also possible interpretations for the prophecy; matching these carefully to create the oracles' signature rhyming couplets will lead to victory.

If you survey the board and do not like your odds for the future, you may also turn to the past for aid. Each game one of ten possible supplicants will be chosen at the beginning of play. Their branching past will be revealed as cards are played, and with it, shrines offering powerful abilities will awaken.

View the past, predict the future, and outwit your opponents to prove yourself worthy of becoming the next Head Oracle.

-description from the designer

A game about saying anything to get a sale. Sell Outs is a tabletop card game about solving curious problems with absurd creative solutions! This turn-based game is best with 3-7 players, but can be played with more.

Are you plagued by honey badgers? Not getting that raise you want at work? Have you ever had trouble starting a revolution? Everyone has problems. Now you have solutions!

Sell Outs is the game of solving your friend’s problems by pitching common items with odd features!
A crane that grants wishes that always backfire. A spaceship that does not need any fuel, but flies really slowly. A rabbit’s foot that doubles as a great wingman. Anything is possible when you Sell Out!

—description from the publisher

The object of the game is to be the first player to build a 16-floor building. At the same time, players will attempt to prevent their opponents from reaching their 16th floor. The first player to build their 16th floor and also hold the "Finished Building" card will be the winner.

Apart from the tiles used for the buildings, there are also cards which are used to defend against other players. Attacks are also played through cards, including snowstorms, worker strikes, and lack of concrete, among other problems.

—user summary

People today spend much of their time on their undervalued, uninteresting daily work. Whether it is to achieve a better standard of living, improving their homes, their health, or supporting their children’s career, for many this might mean delaying the full enjoyment of their own life and long-held dreams. Financial independence is more important than ever. Proper, well-made investments can increase the value of your assets and earn you profit. Smart investment of that profit can eventually help you achieve financial independence.

In Money On FIRE, the goal is financial independence. Each player has three targets represented by three cards. Once any player fulfills all three targets set out in their cards, and so becomes financially independent, they win the game. Two to four players can choose different ways to invest, such as the property investment, building up their own business to win the best possible contracts, investing time to level up their professional knowledge in a tech tree, making investments in bonds and so on, all to build the most efficient investment portfolio.

—description from the designer

Each player get a 10x10 squares grid. Two Tetris-like pentominoes are associated with each numbers 1 to 6.
The game is played in real time: a dice throw determines a combination of two pentominoes, each player must choose one and draw it on his/her sheet connected to the bottom or on top of preexisting full squares in a gravity-affected fashion. The shapes can be rotated at will before being drawn. At the end of the round, player rotate their sheet 90° clockwise. Repeat until every player can't place a piece during a round.
The number of completed columns OR rows gives the score. The player(s) with the highest score win(s).

Kutu Buku: A Game of Nerdy Talk is a social-party game that combines the elements of trivia game with bluffing. In turns, players will be the Active Player who talks about certain topic. Active Player has to choose whether they want to tell the story truthfully or fabricate it. The other players will discuss it, then they will vote either the story is a fact or faked. Active Player and others who guess correctly will get point(s) as many as the number of players who guess otherwise. Try not to be too predictable, since if all the players voted unanimously and correctly, you will get penalty! The game will run until 2 rounds, or 1 round if we play with 6-8 players.

Dive into the magnificent era of the Renaissance, with playing this authentic game including all expansion modules.

You belong to the best fresco painters and are hired to restore the ceiling painting in the cathedral to its former glory. Put your skills to the test to win the bishop’s favour and thus the game.

This Mega Box includes new artwork and combines the basic game with all modules (1-17). These can be combined with the basic game as desired, thus extending the playing possibilities. Each module also influences the duration of the game – for even more and longer lasting fun!

—description from publisher

Light Hunters is a team-based fighting game set in a heroic fantasy universe. The aim of the game is to crush the other team. In order to do that, you select a hero belonging to one of the 4 classes available: tank, fighter, healer or spellcaster.

Light Hunters is the perfect game to ruin a friendship or to decide who will do the chores in your relationship. Opening the game is like opening a famous ancient box…

Pandora Edition is exclusive to the Kickstarter campaign, the box art has been redesigned and an holographic effect will be applied.

Contains:

- Base game in a unique box edition
- Expansion cycle I: Rise of the East & Dawn of Amazonia
- Expansion cycle II: Wind of the Dunes & Tide of Atlantis 
- All unlocked stretch goals

Stretch Goals:

- Sturdier cards
- Alternative art for the Spirits of Light
- One size of the Hero card will be printed with silver ink

Empress is a world of exotic steam and punk in which a one-eyed despot rules supreme. It is a world of indentured peons and hardworking mules, traveling tinker bands and perspiring fixers bathed in furnace glow. Merchantmen anchor off far-flung ports while rank upon rank of Her Majesty's rifles assemble in faceless obedience. A darkened corner could turn up one of Turing's programmatic spies while, ensconced underground, seers break through into a kaleidoscope of forbidden futures. Here, there are dukes (one mad), princelings with dark pasts and kings and queens of uncertain allegiance. Overhead, her Highness's trusted fighting aces rule the skies; beneath, her elephantine automatons shake the very ground.

In this realm, the all-seeing, all-knowing tentacles of the Great Empress reach far and wide. So wide, in fact, that many have despaired of freedom and—at a glance of her one baleful eye—life itself. But there is hope: a tale overheard in the fevered ruminations of a nameless prophet speaks of a day when one of her subjects will approach the throne, wrench the cephalopodic scepter from her grasp and end the reign of terror. But who?

Welcome to Empress, a climbing game of cunning, strategy and power. The premise? Be the first to shed all of your cards and ascend the throne of the Great Empress. But beware—a tragic misstep and you could find yourself wallowing in drudgery as a Peon or Mule. Empress may be played with any number of players from 2 to 8 (add a second deck for 5 or more).

—description from the publisher

Journey through the Magical Forest to find a Golden Unicorn and Majestic Unicorn. Add them to your stable to win the game. Your journey is not without challenges. Beware of foul mystical beings, potions, and magic as they may hinder your quest. This is a strategy card game and perfect for people of all ages. A must have for all unicorn enthusiast!

Game Information
Players: 2-6
Time: 15-40 min
Age: 8+

Components
40 Mystical Being cards
20 Mystical Potion cards
15 Mystical Magic cards
6 Reference sheet
1 Rule book
1 Box

2-4 Players
Ages 12+
30 min. per player

SUMMARY:
In the year 2475 world nations race to save the past and control the use of time travel.

STORY:
The amount of anomalies created through time travel in the 25th century has become a major world concern. The FTCN (Federation of Time-Traveling Capable Nations) has voted that all nations must give up their time travel capabilities. A single task force of “time editors” (agents that specialize in changing the timeline) will be kept on standby in the event that they are needed to save humanity from any possible future disasters. Only the nation with the most skilled time editors will retain their use of time travel. The task force of time editors will be chosen through a “time editing” trial. The first nation to prevent four disastrous past events will retain the use of time travel and will have command of the official global task force of time editors.â€‹

PLAY:
The game is a blend of:
• resource and economy management
• a worker placement system in the present and past
• storytelling

To win the game you must prevent 4 disastrous events in the past from happening.
 Player mats have two halves - past and present. People and resources you take to the past can only be used in the past. People and resources you keep in the present can only be used in the present. Each player has 4 types of time editing specialists: Science, Technology, Military, and Politics. Specialists have unique abilities when they are in the present, but when they travel back in time to change the past you lose their abilities in the present.

You can send 1 to 4 specialists back in time if you have the necessary resources. Sending multiple, or all, at once will reduce the wormhole resources needed by reducing the number of time jumps (1 per turn). But keeping some specialists in the present will allow you to use their abilities to strengthen your economy, intelligence, and undermine other nations. Who and when you send where is your choice!

Each player is given unique disasters in the past that they will need to prevent. (There are 16 time lines with 80 unique events). In order to change the time line and prevent a disaster, you must change the events leading up to the disaster. Certain specialists are needed to change specific events but you can decide which event you travel to. Attempts at changing the time line involve storytelling (a game tester favorite!) and pulling tiles to create ripples through time.

In order to time travel and pay specialists to change the past, you will need an economy. There are over 130 possible economic setups with variable risk/reward factors. Players explore planets, build mining colonies, mine resources and transport them to Earth. Planets further from Earth have richer mining deposits but will take longer to reach (unless you can afford to create wormholes or pay to use other players’ wormholes).

Resources can only be used once they are returned to Earth, so you will need to plan ahead multiple turns for where/when your time ship will be and which specialists are where/when. Resources can be used to buy items for your economy, buy action cards (draw 3 & choose 1), open wormholes in space (for faster travel to planets), open wormholes in time (to change the past), pay time editing specialists to change the past, or hire A. I. to give you the probability of causing a time ripple.

—description from the publisher

In Jogakbo, a.k.a. ì¡°ê°ë³´ (Korean for "patchwork"), you are a member of the Seolbo Artisan Group — "ì„¤" (seol) referring to both harmony and a piece of silk — and your group has been challenged to assemble a beautiful quilt from whatever silk pieces they have available in their shops. Who will create the most harmonious quilt that satisfies the client's demands?

To set up, each player receives their own 8x8 game board, playing on either the easy or normal side of the board. The board features a 2x2 central space as well as a number of holes and spots for ornamentation. You lay out two main order cards and one secondary order card at random, along with 5-9 pieces of silk cloth in the four colors, adjusting the quantity based on the player count. Additionally, you have high-quality silk patches that cover either a 1x1 or 2x1 space, with these pieces being of a fifth and sixth color. Place one piece of silk of the main four colors on the matching spaces on the market board. Give each player three coins, with the start player taking an additional coin.

On a turn, you can either move the token on the market board to a different color and take the silk piece and any coins from this space, or pay 2 coins to choose any silk piece from the main four colors, whether from the market board or in the reserves. (The start player can place the token on any of the four colors on the first turn.) You then place the silk on your board. Your first piece must cover at least one square in the center of your game board; each subsequent piece must lie orthogonally adjacent to a piece already on your board, and pieces of the same color cannot be adjacent to one another!

If you cover an ornament space on your board, you can pay a coin to take a high-quality silk piece and place it on your board. If you cover another ornament space, you can do this again. To end your turn, (if needed) choose a silk piece from the reserve of the same color that you took and place it on the market board, then place a coin from the bank on any market space that doesn't have the token in it.

Whenever you achieve a secondary order during play, such as covering a hole with high-quality silk or placing a second piece of the same shape, you receive a bonus immediately.

After eight rounds, the game ends. You receive a bonus based on how well you completed the main orders, such as creating a silk-filled square or filling the diagonals of your board. Additionally, each filled vertical or horizontal line is worth 3 points, each uncovered ornament 1 point, each hole -1 point, and each coin 1 point as long as you have at least three coins. Whoever has the highest score wins.

The Legend of Drimek is a co-operative board game for 2-4 players in which you take control of one of the heroes from the kingdom of Drimek, one of the four allies that live to search for treasures and relics in the depths of the dungeons.

But one day, they discover an open gate that had been closed for centuries. When they access the dungeon and collect all the treasures, they accidentally wake up an evil necromancer from its slumber, who entraps them in the testing grounds. That's why our heroes must find a way to escape the testing grounds, by cooperating to fight and solve the different tests that each level will throw at them to return to their home. It seems like the testing grounds' legend is true. The Legend of Drimek is real.

—description from the publisher

The moment is finally there, ‘the’ ultimate relationship test starts again and you and your friends are allowed to cause chaos on the island as seducers. You have a clear goal, but are you funny, sexy or intelligent enough to seduce that person. Use every trick you got to surpass your fellow players and ensure an extreme result during a campfire. Are you capable of winning this crazy love game and can you conquer ... Temptation Island?

Temptation Island is a fun party/card game that contains cards, a dice and a game board. The game can be played with up to 6 players. The goal of the game is to collect a certain number of cards. The cards can be obtained by seducing other players with a clever text. Players take turns playing a card that misses a piece of text. Depending on the time of the day, all the other players try to be the funniest, sexiest or smartest player to complete the sentence on the card.

—description from the publisher

Experience the exotic adventure in your own living room. Lead a camp with expedition members and compete to become the ultimate Robinson. Prepare for the tests and use your votes to vote other players away. Do you survive ‘De Eilandraad’ and win this adventurous board game?

Expeditie Robinson De eilandraad is a complete new board game based on the television program. The game is a survival draft game where players try to strengthen their team to prepare for tests. The team that survives a test is allowed to vote other team members away. The team with the last man standing wins the board game.

—description from the publisher

YOU AND YOUR TEAM HAVE BEEN SEND ON A MISSION TO CRACK 3 IMPORTANT CODES. ALL TEAM MEMBERS ARE IN POSSESSION OF DIFFERENT CODES AND KEYS. BY WORKING TOGETHER IT IS POSSIBLE TO SOLVE THE MYSTERY AROUND THE CODES, BUT WHAT IF THERE IS ONE PERSON THAT WANTS TO SABOTAGE EVERYTHING? WHO CAN YOU TRUST DURING YOUR MISSION AND WHO IS THE MOL?

De Mol De code-opdracht is a cooperative social deduction board game.  
Players work together to try to solve 3 codes on the board by combining a set of dice. While doing so 1 player is de mol and tries to stop the other players from solving the code. But he must do this without being noticed. The game is playable with up to 6 players and takes about 45 minutes. The game has his own app with an AR-function to play an advanced version of the game.

—description from the publisher

Wilah is an educational card with environment theme. Suitable for children, lecturer, environmentalist, or parent who want to teach about how to sort the waste. Wilah can be played by 2-6 player with age 7 and above for 5-15 minutes per game. Wilah involve player's cognitive aspect to sort the waste based on the material and involve player's motoric aspect.

To play, deal the deck out as evenly as possible to every player. Make sure the card remain unrevealed. One by one, each player take the topmost card and stack it to the place that reachable for every player. Under certain condition, player will slap the card and shout "Wilah!". These conditions are :


     If three cards show the same color or waste category
     If two cards show the identical image
     If one card show waste processing or trashbin


The first player that succeed to slap and shout "Wilah!" can keep all the card with the same category or color as that player slap can. Those card counted as coin. Player with the most coin win the game.

—description from the publisher

5 Different Battlefleet Games

Free! Dr. Scratchov Scratcher!

disposable games to scratch, play & throw away

Objective:  You are in a fierce naval battle in dense foggy weather.  Your mission is to find and sink all five of your opponent's ships before he does the same to you.

Preparation:  Each player scratches the center of the battleship on their own side of the card to reveal their color code of ships in the game.  One player has red ships, the other player had blue ships.  Each player has one Battleship (four sections long). two Cruisers (three sections long), and two Destroyers (two sections long).

How to Play:  Beginning with the red player, take turns scratching any one square.  By doing so, a player both removes the "fog" and takes a "shot" at that square.  Because of the fog, a player may accidentally hit part of his own ship, as sometimes happens in real life.  Be careful!

When all the sections of a ship are hit, the ship is sunk.

The Mine:  When either player hits a mine, it explodes, and that player immediately scratches all eight surrounding squares if they haven't already been scratched.  This will usually cause damage to both player's ships.

—user summary

5 Different Bermuda Triangles Games

Free! Dr. Scratchov Scratcher!

disposable games to scratch, play & throw away

OBJECTIVE:  An invasion of UFOs is hovering over the Bermuda Triangle.  You operate a series of Coast Guard Rescue Stations located just outside the area.

YOUR MISSION: pilot rescue choppers into the dangerous Triangle in search of human survivors.  But don't let the UFOs zap you out of the Solar System.

HOW TO PLAY (solo version):  You have enough choppers for six rescue flights.  Start each mission by scratching the triangle in front of any rescue station, indicated by a black dot along the sides of the large triangle.  From there, fly in any direction by scratching any triangle that is next to the space you currently occupy.
  
Continue flying through the triangles in search of human ships.  You can move one space at a time, in any direction you desire.  Some spaces will be empty, but others will reveal the following:
 DINGY - 1 person aboard

ROWBOAT - 3 people aboard

YACHT - 7 people aboard

CLIPPER - 10 people aboard

UFO - Zap! A UFO abducts you and all your passengers back to Andromeda to work as slaves in a pyramid factory.  This ends that mission and you score no points.  There are about half a dozen UFOs hiding in the triangles, mostly near the outside edge.

RADAR - Radar indicates that a ship larger than a dingy lies in the direction shown within four spaces.
MISSION - Uncovering an "M" give you fuel for an extra mission, if you can return safely from your present one.  If your are capture by a UFO before returning, you lose the extra mission and all the survivors on this trip.

To rescue survivors, you must get them out by flying off any side of the Triangle without running into a UFO. This ends the mission and allows you to score 1 point for each survivor you picked up.  You can fly out of the Triangle right away, or take a chance searching for more survivors before heading out.  Each mission must start from a new rescue station and, since you don't want to waste fuel searching an area twice, a new mission path cannot cross over an old one.

Rescue 50 or more humans to win the game.

TWO PLAYER VERSION - The game plays the same except that players take turns for 3 missions each.  The player rescuing the most humans wins.

—user summary

OBJECTIVE:  Your are the groundskeeper of an exclusive golf course that has been invaded by six pesky moles (each a different color).  See and destroy the rascals!  The player with the most points after all six moles have been caught wins.

PREPARATION - Write the player's initials in the coring area.  Players then scratch the squares on the bottom of the card to determine who goes first.  The player finding the number "1" starts the game by digging the first hole (scratching a circle). The moles you seek are pink, blue, black, yellow, green and purple.

HOW TO PLAY - To find moles, you "dig" holes on the golf course by scratching any circle.  You can find all sorts of stuff in a hole - information on where the moles are hiding, bonus points, or nasty traps the moles have set for you!  After each hole is dug, the turn passes to the next player on the left (unless otherwise stated).  Use hashmarks in the scoring area to keep score.  Here is what you might dig up:

MOLE - 5 points
GOLF BALL - 1 point
POISON GOLF BALL - Minus 1 point
SNAKE (Hiss!) - Lose your next turn
MOLE POOP - Lose your next turn
EMPTY HOLE - Nothing, zip, zero.

Digging up the following items will give you important information:

FLASHLIGHTS - Shine light on moles of the same color.  The mole will be somewhere within the "total area of circles" defined by the direction of the "beam of light".  This helpful light also allows you to continue your turn.

MOLE HOLES - The mole of this color is somewhere in line with this symbol.

MOLE METER - A number 2, 3 or 4.  There is a mole (of this color) that number of circles away.

DYNAMITE - It blows up!  You must scratch off all the neighboring circles that surround the explosive and score them as normal.

—user summary

5 Different Boomtown Baseball Games

Free! Dr. Scratchov Scratcher!

disposable games to scratch, play & throw away

OBJECTIVE:  The Boomtown "Bats" are hosting their archrivals, The Mudville "Muggers", in another classic confrontation at famous Boomtown Stadium!  It's the top of the ninth,  Neither team has scored.  Who will win this critical game?

PREPARATION:  Choose your team.  The teams bat with a lineup of four batters picked at random from their full team of nine.  A batter's lifetime "stats" are shown below his name.  The batting order starts at the top (near the pitch indicators) and is repeated if necessary by returning to #1 as the fifth batter.  Keep track of all base runner with pennies placed on the baseball diamond.  The "Muggers" bat first.

HOW TO PLAY:  The pitcher throws each ball by placing his finger tip on the pitch of his choice and announcing either "fast ball", "curve ball", or "slider".  The other player then scratches any one of his four "swing" boxes" under the pitch for the player he has at bat (if all a batter's swing boxes are scratched for one type of pitch, the pitcher must throw something else). It will reveal one of the following results:

HR (Home Run)  - It's a hit out of the park.  The batter and all runners score.

X (Strike) - Get 3 strikes and the batter is out.

W (Walk) - The batter advances to first base.

G (Grounder) - It's a hit.  The pitching team must play the ball.  The pitcher scratches any one of his ten "Infield" squares to see the results of the play.

FB (Fly Ball) - It's a  hit.  The pitching team must play the ball.  The pitcher scratches any one his ten "Outfield" squares to see the results of the play.

When and Grounder or Fly Ball is played by the pitcher the following things can result:
S (Single) - The batter and all runners advance one base.
D (Double) - The batter and all runners advance two bases.
T (Triple) - The batter and all runners advance three bases.
HR (Home Run) - The batter and all runners score.
O (Out) - The batter is out.
DP (Double Play) - The batter and the furthest advanced runner (if there is one) are out.  Scratch two out squares on the scoreboard.

Keep track of "Runs" and "Outs" by scratching the squares left to right on the score board.  After the "Muggers" have made three outs, the roles reverse and the "Bats" come up to the plate.  After the "Bats" have three outs, the game is over.  The team with the highest score wins.  In the event of a tie, play another card for "extra innings".

SPECIAL HINT:  You will notice, after playing a few games, that each of the nine batters on each team always bats exactly the same way every time.  For example, Homer Bundy, the slugger Right Fielder for the "Muggers", always hits a home run if you pitch him a fast ball.  The more you know about each batter, the better you can pick the right pitch or choose the right swing.  Fast ball pitches tent to either be hit hard or get a strike.  Sliders tend to produce grounders, and curve balls tend to produce a lot of fly balls and walks.

—user summary

You were just a normal pencil-neck geek working on your computer when suddenly, it filled the room with weird radiation and turned you into a 150-foot tall monster - GEEKZILLA!  You go on a rampage downtown and collect everything you find!

Decide who goes first.  Take turns scratching any window on the sky-scrapers to see what you find inside.  You score points depending on what interesting things are found in the window.  Keep track of your points in your head or by writing on the scoring building.

After all windows have been broken into, the player who has scored the most points wins the game!  You will see:

GIRL IN TOWEL - 50 points.  She screams at you!

COMPUTER - 25 points.  A geekzilla's best friend!

DOG - 10 points.  A geekzilla's second best friend!

VIDEO GAMES - 5 points.  (Clue: a computer is in one of the nearby windows!)

SECURITY GUARD - 0 points.  For some reason, they shoot at you if you try to grab them.  Leave them alone.

BROKEN GLASSES - Oh no!  Your opponent takes 2 turns in a row while you fix your glasses.

—user summary

Friendly parents on Mars are trying to escape to freedom on Earth, but the evil Martian politicians are turning them into mutants!  You have just arrived in your rescue ships and are battling to save the parents.  After all spaces are scratched, the player who has rescued the most pairs of Moms and Dads is the winner!

Decide who goes first.  Take turns.  Each turn scratch any 2 spaces on the planet.  There are 4 different things you can find: A MOM, DAD, MARTIAN OR EXPLOSION.  Match both spaces you scratched to see what happens:

Mom + DAD - Perfect match!  Score one of each on your rescue ship and take another turn!

MOM + MOM - Score 2 Moms.  You saved them!

DAD + DAD - Score 2 Dads.  You saved them!

Martian + Mom or Dad - Oh no!  Your opponent scores the Mom or Dad while you fight the Martian Off!

DOUBLE MARTIANS - Your opponent gets to take 2 turns in a row while you fight the Martians off!

EXPLOSION + ANYTHING - An explosion destroys whatever else you scratched.  No points scored!

DOUBLE EXPLOSION - Awesome!  Martians watch the fireworks while you take another turn!

—user summary

Roll Estate is a love letter to the classics, where you’ll roll and write your way to wealth in a race to become the richest entrepreneur! Roll the dice three times to acquire loads of rental property, open bold new businesses, try your luck with some risky investments, and perhaps even win the lottery! Can you turn five dice into cool cash?

Players roll dice three times, keeping whatever they want between rolls, then use the result to claim an Asset. Each Asset in the game requires different combinations of dice to claim.

There are eight neighborhoods, each with 2-3 Rental Properties to be claimed. Players claim Rental Properties by entering sums of qualifying dice. The values entered must increase from left to right, and the first player to claim all Rental Properties in a row gets to open a Business for a big bonus (which all other players immediately cross out). Most rows have room for two Businesses of decreasing value, while others only contain one, leading players to compete for them before they are gone. Once a player opens a third business, this signals the end of the game.

Players can also roll sequences of four to claim shares of the Mass Transit system, each of which can only be claimed by one player...larger sets pay out more money. And players can put the sum of one roll into Liquid Assets, which can then be multiplied by Stock Indexes (claimed with a sequence of five).

—description from the designer

Fou fou fou is a party game in which you just have to read the rule written on the card you draw and do what is written on this card. Every time.
There are more and more rules to remember! 
If one player forgets one of the rules, he loses one point. If you lose your third point, you lose the game.

Lord of the Chords is a classical music themed, card drafting set collection game for 2-4 players that has real music theory  cleverly woven into its game mechanics. Prepare for augmented fun, major geeky learning, and diminished boredom!

Players begin by choosing 1 of 13 musical instruments that grant variable player powers. To win the game, players must draft the right Note cards to their hands, according to the active Key Signature tile. Notes are then played to the field, and combined to form Chords. When a Chord that matches the current Key Signature is completed by a player, that Key Signature Tile is claimed! The first Player to collect 3 Key Signatures is the Bringer of Harmony, the Destroyer of Dissonance, the Lord of the Chords!

On your turn, you first draft 3 cards, then make 3 moves. You may spend your moves by (1) playing a Note card, or (2) playing an Action card.

Other ways to spend moves include: (A) Moving a Note card from one chord to another, (B) buying Accidental Tokens, or (C) spending 2 moves to draft 1 additional card.

Note cards must be diatonic to be played, according to the active Key Signature. Action cards range from punny composer cards like “More-zart”, which allows you to draw 2 more cards, to powerful music theory concepts like “Major 7th Steal”, which allows you to turn the tables by stealing another player's hard earned Key Signature tile!

Accidental Tokens make it easier to complete chords. They are placed on Note cards to raise or lower the note by a semitone/half step, depending on whether the sharp or flat side is facing up, respectively. Accidental tokens are bought by selling a dotted quarter note/dotted crotchet worth of Note cards.

All cards are drafted from a pool of 6 cards, so memory, prediction and counter-strategizing are key to victory. Every play is noteworthy - you can't miss a beat!

The player who most recently practiced music goes first, so go practice!

—description from the designer
